title: Willie Cameron
text:
William Smith Cameron (2 December 1883 – 14 October 1958) was a Scottish <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player and <a href="Manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a> whose position was mainly as an <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29%23Inside%20forward">inside forward</a>, though he was versatile and also played in the <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29%23Centre-forward">centre</a>, on the <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29%23Outside%20forward">wing</a> and at <a href="Midfielder%23Wing%20half">half back</a> during his career.
Playing career.
Cameron's playing career, during which he acquired the nickname 'Kilty', was largely characterised by short periods at several clubs in northern England and south-west Scotland. Born at <a href="Mossend">Mossend</a>, <a href="Lanarkshire">Lanarkshire</a>, though much of his early life was spent in <a href="Coatbridge">Coatbridge</a> where his father worked in the local ironworks, he moved to <a href="Bolton%20Wanderers%20F.C.">Bolton Wanderers</a> owing to that town's connections to heavy industry, having initially moved south to play for <a href="Glossop%20North%20End%20A.F.C.">Glossop</a>.
His longest spell was at <a href="Blackburn%20Rovers%20F.C.">Blackburn Rovers</a>, where he spent <a href="List%20of%20Blackburn%20Rovers%20F.C.%20seasons">five seasons</a> and was part of the squad that won the <a href="Football%20League">Football League</a> championship in <a href="1911%E2%80%9312%20Football%20League">1911–12</a>, alongside the likes of fellow Scots <a href="Walter%20Aitkenhead">Walter Aitkenhead</a>, <a href="Johnny%20Orr%20%28footballer%29">Johnny Orr</a> and <a href="Jock%20Simpson">Jock Simpson</a>; he was not an undisputed regular in the team at <a href="Ewood%20Park">Ewood Park</a>, but his ability to fill in at several positions meant he was often called upon. On paper, he was also contracted to <a href="Hull%20City%20A.F.C.">Hull City</a> for five years, but in reality he only played there for 18 months before <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> led to the cancellation of official competitions in English football; he had a number of short loans at clubs in the <a href="Greater%20Glasgow">Greater Glasgow</a> area (the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League">Scottish Football League</a> continued) and served in the <a href="Royal%20Army%20Ordnance%20Corps">Royal Army Ordnance Corps</a> during the conflict.
At representative level, he appeared in the <a href="Home%20Scots%20v%20Anglo-Scots">Home Scots v Anglo-Scots</a> annual trial match in 1909 but did not gain any full <a href="Cap%20%28sport%29">caps</a> for <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a>.
Managerial career.
In 1919, Cameron became player-manager of <a href="Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Second Division</a> <a href="Bury%20F.C.">Bury</a> and spent <a href="List%20of%20Bury%20F.C.%20seasons">four seasons</a> in charge of the "Shakers" before being issued with a life ban in 1923 following an investigation into an incident three years earlier when Bury were found to have accepted payments from <a href="Coventry%20City%20F.C.">Coventry City</a> officials to deliberately lose their end-of-season fixture and save Coventry from relegation at the expense of <a href="Lincoln%20City%20F.C.">Lincoln City</a> (the extent of his involvement in the incident is not clear).
Cameron's ban was eventually lifted in 1929 and he managed <a href="Rochdale%20A.F.C.">Rochdale</a> for the unsuccessful <a href="1930%E2%80%9331%20Rochdale%20A.F.C.%20season">1930–31 season</a> when they had to seek re-election to the <a href="Football%20League%20Third%20Division%20North">Third Division North</a>, and the first half of <a href="1931%E2%80%9332%20Rochdale%20A.F.C.%20season">1931–32</a> which was equally poor and eventually ended with the same outcome.
Later life.
Cameron settled with his family in <a href="Bolton">Bolton</a>, where by the outbreak of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> in 1939 he was working at the <a href="de%20Havilland%20Propellers">de Havilland Propellers</a> factory. He was not related to <a href="Jock%20Cameron%20%28footballer%29">Jock Cameron</a>, another Blackburn Rovers player of the era who also grew up in the Coatbridge area and settled in Lancashire.
